Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for clear identification of one of the following:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: When the melting point range is narrow this implies a pure compound

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A broad range indicates an impure compound.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for either of the following concepts being communicated:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: When the melting point is narrow and it matches the melting point of the pure compound, the identity of the component can be confirmed as being the same as the pure compound.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A small sample of the unknown compound can be mixed with a sample of a pure compound. If the melting point of the mixture was the same as that of the pure compound, the unknown can be confirmed as being the same as the pure compound.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: There is a single chiral centre.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for the correct calculation of n(linalool) = 0.042 / 2 = 0.021 mol

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for the correct m(linalool) = 0.021 × 154 = 3.234 mol

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for the correct percentage m(linalool) = 3.234 / 15.0 = 22%

Content: The first mark was awarded for any valid extraction technique:

Content: Solvent extraction / steam distillation / filtration.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for any valid purification technique:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Distillation (fractional distillation) / HPLC.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Some students attempted to respond to the purification process with 'recrystallisation', but as linalool is identified in the stem of the question as an oil, this could not be accepted.

Content: Students should be aware that they should not provide 'working out' material in the response boxes provided as this can invalidate a correct response.

Content: Students should be aware that a representation such as 'OHCH2CH2CH2CH2CH3' is an incorrect representation of a terminal hydroxyl group.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Either propan-1-ol or 1-propanol were acceptable responses. Both of these follow IUPAC nomenclature conventions.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Any of the following qualitative tests were accepted for the first mark.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was associated with the correct observation applicable to the test chosen.

Subject: Chemistry
Content:
* The indicator must be able to undergo a distinct colour change at a pH less than 7.
** Normally the smell is described as 'sweet' or 'fruity', but any 'smell' was accepted as a significant number of students would have manufactured biodiesel as part of their laboratory work and biodiesels do not have this type of 'fruity' smell.
*** Group 1 metals were not accepted as these produce gas if any labile hydrogen is present, and therefore cannot be used to identify the compound specifically as a carboxylic acid.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Incorrect responses such as 'limewater test' could not be awarded marks as this tests the product of the reaction between a carboxylic acid and a metal carbonate, not the carboxylic acid itself. The addition of an acid to limewater produces a salt and water, which cannot be observed.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: In order to gain these marks for the limewater test, the student needed to indicate that the unknown organic compound had to be reacted with a metal carbonate first, and the gas produced then tested using the limewater test to confirm the presence of carbon dioxide being evolved.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A clear skeletal diagram was required as represented below.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The only significant issue that arose from this question related to the fact that some students did not use the box provided on page 14 (as specified in the question) and instead provided their response in the blank space at the bottom of page 15. Students are reminded to provide responses in the correct location on the examination.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Students needed to calculate the correct value for the energy released, with units.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Peptide bond/link or amide bond/link

Content: The reaction type is a condensation reaction.

Content: Either of leucine or serine was accepted.

Content: Many students were unable to successfully identify either of these compounds.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Students needed to identify that oleic acid has just one C=C present in its structure, and that stearic acid does not have a C=C. This response could also have been represented by stating that oleic acid had two fewer hydrogens present in its structure compared with stearic acid.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Students needed to be careful and not state that stearic had 'no double bonds', as this could not be accepted.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: When asked to identify a difference, a direct comparison of the two compounds is usually required. It was insufficient to provide a response such as 'Oleic acid has one C=C double bond' as this did not indicate whether the stearic has no C=C bonds or has multiple C=C bonds.

Content: The first mark was awarded for correctly identifying two bond types that differed in the structures of oleic acid and stearic acids and then using the data provided in the Data Book to predict the greatest enthalpy change.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded to students who correctly identified an extra bond type that enhanced their prediction.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: It was common to see responses gain the first mark for the comparison of data for the C=C (614 kJ) associated with oleic acid and either the C-C (346 kJ) or the C-H (414 kJ) of stearic acid. The second mark was harder to obtain as fewer responses demonstrated that ½(O=O) or 2(O-H) were also involved in the enthalpy change.

Content: The first mark was awarded for any one of the following three valid stresses that caused Q  K:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Removal of product / addition of reactant / reduction in volume (increase in all partial pressures).

Content: The second mark was awarded for the correct identification of the forward shift in the equilibrium.

Content: The third mark was awarded for a description of how this shift applied to either:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The partial changes in quantities associated with the stress

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Restoring the equilibrium so that Q = K.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Some responses did not gain full marks as they failed to provide sufficiently specific responses that linked directly to the stress they had selected.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Attempts to provide a response based on temperature change could not be accepted as the stem of the question emphasised that the process occurred at a constant temperature. Students are reminded to fully read the stem of each question.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for a clear identification of what the term 'conflict' related to in terms of the optimal rate and temperature when ammonia is being produced. A good example showing detailed understanding of this conflict could have been:

Subject: Chemistry
Example: Due to the exothermic nature of the equilibrium, at high temperature the rate of formation of ammonia is high but the yield will be low, whereas at low temperature the rate of formation of ammonia is too slow but the yield is very high.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for a clear statement that linked the presence of the catalyst to allowing a sufficiently fast rate to be occurring at a lower temperature, and hence reducing energy requirements.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for a clear statement that linked the lower temperature requirements with the green chemistry principle of 'catalysis', which states that 'Catalysts ... using less energy and reagents in reaction processes/pathways'. Therefore, a student needed to show reasoning for this choice based on linking the lower temperature to this concept.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Most responses effectively linked the green chemistry principle to this issue, but often did not fully identify the 'conflict' that was asked for in the stem of the question.

Content: The first mark was awarded for the correct calculation of the mole of butane:

Content: The second mark was awarded for calculating the correct quantity of energy released, with units:

Content: The mark was awarded for the correct calculation of the energy change of the water, with units:

Content: It was concerning to see some responses using the density of water, 0.997, in these calculations as, even if it was relevant, this was only applicable in the previous study design and Data Book.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for the correct calculation of the % energy efficiency.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for the value being quoted to three significant figures.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for the response demonstrating that a solution calorimeter needs to be calculated because energy is needed to heat the water and it is needed to heat the internal components of the calorimeter; that is, energy from the reaction is not solely transferred to the water (hence why q = mC∆T cannot be used).

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for understanding that, without this calibration factor, we cannot use the change in temperature of an unknown reaction to determine an accurate value for the enthalpy change. Without calibration, the enthalpy value obtained will always be less than the true value for a given calorimeter using a fixed quantity of solution.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for the correct calculation of energy released, with units:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Energy released(based in limiting reagent) = 0.048 × 24.5 = 1.176 kJ or 1176 J

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for the correct change in temperature:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Change in temperature = 1176 / 470 = 2.5 °C

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for the correct final temperature:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Maximum temperature reached = 25.0 + 2.5 = 27.5 °C

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Errors occurred when:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The stoichiometry was not taken into account when determining the energy released

Subject: Chemistry
Content: There was no consideration of the units of the energy and the calibration factor

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Responses determined a negative energy released and subtracted the temperature change.

Content: The amount of KI added to the calorimeter was too high.

Content: The total volume of solution in the calorimeter was lower than that used to calibrate it.

Content: The calorimeter's calibration factor was smaller than the true value.

Content: Students should avoid attempting to use 'm/z' as a unit (for example, '56 m/z').

Content: The integration curve is a representation of the area of a signal for a hydrogen environment or a 'peak area'.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: This question was not well answered, and often responses to Question 6d.ii were repeat answers. Careful reading of the question was needed to understand the correct terminology that applied to each of these two questions.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The relative size of an integration curve is proportional to the ratio or the relative number of hydrogens present in that hydrogen environment.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The relative size of an integration curve shown in the table indicates that the ratio of hydrogens present in each of the compound's four hydrogen environments are 1:2:2:6.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: This question was not well answered, and often responses did not relate understanding of these integration curves back to the structure of Compound X.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for understanding that the peak at 0.96 suggests that an R-CH3 group is present.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for linking the information from Question 6d.iii and stating that therefore there must be two R-CH3 groups present in Compound X.

Content: This question was assessed for the use of states.

Content: Students need to be aware that for reactions that occur during a specific redox process, the single-headed arrow '→' is required.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A significant number of students responded to this question by writing an equation based on either iron or platinum reacting. It is recommended that students sketch out a diagram of the cell to assist them to understand the processes occurring at each electrode.

Content: Any of the following were valid responses:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: One of the products of the reaction is hydrogen gas, which does not stay in contact with the electrode and therefore is not available to react spontaneously.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Iron(II) hydroxide would form and may not remain in contact with the electrode, and therefore is not available to react spontaneously.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: There are no oxidants/reductants present that are strong enough to react spontaneously with a reductant/oxidant.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Students needed to provide a specific response - statements such as 'this is a non-spontaneous process' do not demonstrate the required understanding of chemical processes.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Electrode X is positive during recharging.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Electrons are continually generated at the anode and used up at the cathode, hence maintaining the charge balance.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: H+ ions are continually generated at the anode and flow to the cathode where they are removed, hence maintaining the charge balance.

Content: The flow of electrons to the cathode is balanced by the flow of protons to the cathode.

Content: Ions flow through the system to balance the charge.

Content: The percentage atom economy is higher for reaction P2 with 89% compared to reaction P1, which is 72%.

Content: In general, this question was well answered, although some students either calculated the % atom economy or the % yield, rather than both of these as required.

Content: The first mark was awarded for identifying % atom economy as the relevant green chemistry principle, as % yield is not specifically addressed as a green chemistry principle.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for responding that the % atom economy for reaction P2 was better aligned with this green chemistry principle because it had the higher % atom economy.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Reaction P1 produces waste ethanoic acid (with other contaminates).

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Reaction P2 produces wastewater (with other contaminates).

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Reaction P1 has a much higher yield, and therefore potentially produces much less waste.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Reaction P2 has a much lower yield, and therefore potentially produces much greater waste.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Recycling of ethanoic acid or unused reactants can reduce the waste from reaction P1.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Two significant issues arose in responses to this question.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Some responses did not show an understanding of how to convert m3 to L. This conversion was given in Item 4 of the Databook. At this stage in the calculations, this led to considerable issues when students attempted to determine the limiting reagent.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Some responses did not establish the quantity of excess reagent that remained after the reaction.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first two marks were awarded for establishing the n(O2) present in the 0.125 m3 container (125 L).

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Or

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for correct calculation of n(excess reagent).

Subject: Chemistry
Content: N(O2)excess = n(O2)inital − n(O2)needed = 1.058 − (5 x 0.2045) = 0.0355 mol

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The fourth mark was awarded for correct mass calculation of excess reagent with units.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for stating or recognising that the energy content of ethanol is less than the energy content of propane in both kJ g-1 or kJ mol-1.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Heat of combustion(ethanol) = 29.7 kJ g-1   <  Heat of combustion(propane) = 40.5 kJ g-1

Subject: Chemistry
Content: ∆H(ethanol) = −1370 kJ  <  ∆H(propane) = −2220 kJ

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for recognising that this difference is due to the partial oxidation of ethanol, which had already occurred with the introduction of the hydroxy group to the molecule.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A common error was stating bond enthalpies as the reason for the different energy content. This could not be accepted without full calculations based on the two complete combustion equations, which is beyond the scope of the study design.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for correctly identifying the oxidation numbers.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: O.N.(Cr3+) = +3 and O.N.(Cr) = 0

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for using these numbers to justify why it was then a reduction process.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: I.e. 'When O.N. decrease, reduction is occurring.'

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The two most common errors were:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Incorrect use of '3+' as an oxidation number

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Incorrect terminology being used when describing the electron transfer during reduction and oxidation processes.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for showing an understanding that for an effective electroplating process, either:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The concentration of Cr3+ in solution should be kept constant; OR

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The rate of decrease of Cr3+ must be the same as the rate of production of Cr3+.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for indicating how the anode and cathode play a role in this. For example, students could have justified this by either of the following, but specific reference to the anode and cathode was required.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Stating that Cr3+ is produced at the anode at the same rate that the Cr3+ is used at the cathode.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Writing the two relevant ½ equations:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: (Anode) Cr(s) → Cr3+(aq) + 3e-    and 	(Cathode) Cr3+(aq) + 3e- → Cr(s)

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A significant number of responses did not recognise the need for a commercial electroplating set-up to have the electrolyte with a constant concentration and were not awarded the first mark.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for relative strength of possible oxidants.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: H+ is a stronger oxidant than Cr3+

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The ½ equation 2H+ + 2e- → H2 is higher on the SEP table than Cr3+ + 3e- → Cr

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for any issue that arises from too much sulfuric acid. Any of:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: H2 will be produced.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: H+ will react spontaneously with the Cr being produced.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: If small quantities of H+ are present and this is below standard 1 M concentrations, H+ reduction reaction is less likely or its position will be moved relative 0.00 V.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for the effect of the issue identified. Any of:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Hydrogen gas produced could be flammable/dangerous.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Chromium plating will not occur.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Chromium plating may be lost if left in solution after the electricity is turned off.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Students found it difficult to use the correct language and often referred to the Cr as an oxidant.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A significant number of responses implied that H2SO4 was a direct source of H2 when added to the solution.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Another aspect that caused confusion related to the aqueous nature of the H2SO4(aq) being added. These responses incorrectly stated that this would introduce water into the reaction, which would cause further reactions.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for the determination of the amount of chromium.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for the determination of the amount of electrons.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for the determination of charge.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The fourth mark was awarded for the determination of the amount of chromium.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Students took two varied approaches in responding to this question, from full mathematical proofs to fully worded explanations.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for showing an understanding that for the same mass of rhodium a smaller amount of electrons was needed. To effectively do this, students needed to recognise that the charge on each ion was identical, so each ion needed the same quantity of electrons to generate the metal atom. With a larger atomic mass, this meant a smaller n(electrons) was needed.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for showing an understanding that for the same period of time, a smaller n(electrons) needs to be transferred and hence a lower current is required to plate the same mass of rhodium.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Mathematically, marks were awarded for recognising:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: (first mark) to plate 7.8 g n(Rh) = 0.0758 mol therefore n(e-) = 0.2274 mol compared to 0.450 mol that was required for chromium.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: (second mark) over 2.5 hours of plating, 2.44 A is needed to plate the Rh, compared to the 4.83 A needed for chromium.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The most common misconceptions were:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Attempting to explain the difference in current needed by trying to compare voltages for the half equations

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Failing to identify that the same charge was present on both cations

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Failing to identify that current and time are inversely related to each other.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Responses needed to state that a reversible reaction is one that can proceed in either direction.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: No marks could be awarded if students attempted to use an equilibrium explanation, i.e. 'rate of forward reaction = rate of reverse reaction'.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for a response indicating that increasing the temperature would cause a backward/reverse shift in the equilibrium based on the forward reaction being exothermic.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for then relating the backward/reverse shift to a decrease in yield.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for stating a stress that would cause a forward shift, for example:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Removing the product

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Adding a reactant

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Increasing the pressure (but only if this was caused by decreasing the volume).

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for providing the rationale as to how the stress caused the shift forward. System moved forward to partially:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Replace the loss of product

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Remove the addition of reactant

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Reduce the number of particles as LHS has 3 particles and RHS has 1 particle.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A significant number of responses just stated that an 'increase in pressure causes a forward shift'. This could not be awarded a mark, as an inert gas will increase the pressure but will not cause a shift forward. Hence responses were required to state not only 'increased pressure' but specifically the means by which it was achieved.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for determining the value of the reaction quotient.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for stating that Q > K.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for showing an understanding that to return Q to K, the system needed to shift backwards / reverse / move to the left so that the products are decreased and reactants increased.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: For any of these equilibrium type questions that involve an initial and final state, while these calculations can be done without the use of a table, it is highly recommended that an I.C.E. table is used, as shown below.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: From the table, x has to be equal to 1.30 M.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for establishing that [CO] = 5.00 - 1.30 = 3.70 M.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for using the equilibrium expression to find [H2]2.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for determining the [H2] = √0.290 = 0.5394 M.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The fourth mark was awarded for determining n(H2)initial.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: [H2]initial = 0.53954 + (2 x 1.30 = 3.14 M  therefore n(H2) = 3.14 mol

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A significant number of students did not realise the need for completing both an I.C.E. table and also an equilibrium expression in order to complete this question.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: For those that did complete the calculations, the most common mistake was that they left their final value as a concentration, not the amount in mol as specified in the stem of the question.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for the correct chemical equation.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for the inclusion of UV light as a requirement of the reaction.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: '1-chloropropane' and 'ammonia' were the two most common responses that were awarded these two marks. (Any primary haloalkane with 3 carbons was accepted.)

Subject: Chemistry
Content: 'propan-1-ol' was also accepted with 'ammonia'.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The stem of the question stated that 'names' should be provided. However, a high proportion of students responded with chemical formulas.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for showing any of the following concepts:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The amount of H-bonding between carboxylic acids is greater than the H-bonding between amines.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Carboxylic acids can form dimers due to the nature of the COOH group.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Carboxylic acids can form stronger intermolecular forces.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for showing an understanding that with either greater forces of attraction or greater masses, more energy is needed to separate the carboxylic acid molecules and hence results in higher boiling points.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Common errors included:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Discussion relating to the strength of C=O and O-H bonds

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Stating that amines only have dispersion forces between molecules.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Amine

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The compound could not be a carboxylic acid as there is no evidence for a carbonyl peak in the spectra or the broad O-H peak of an acid.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The base peak is always shown to have a relative intensity of 100.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The mark was awarded for recognising that all isomers will have the same molecular formulas and therefore all isomers will show the parent ion peak at m/z = 108.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Responses that stated that all isomers have the same molecular mass could not be awarded the mark as the molecular mass of the isomers is 108.5 g mol-1.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: An ideal response by a student would have looked something like the following.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: 'All isomers will have the 35Cl isotope present in 75% of the molecules, and it is the presence of this isotope that is the only thing that produces the parent ion located at m/z = 108.'

Subject: Chemistry
Content: [C3H637ClO]+

Subject: Chemistry
Content: To be awarded this mark, students were required to provide a formula that clearly identified the 37Cl isotope and had an overall single positive charge.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Frequently, responses did not relate the data from the spectra or the table to support the feature of the molecule.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A mark was awarded for any of the following (maximum of 3 marks):

Subject: Chemistry
Content: There were three peaks seen in the spectra, therefore the molecule must have three hydrogen environments.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Each of the three peaks in the spectra are singlets, therefore the molecule must have each hydrogen environment located with no adjacent hydrogens.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The relative peak area of 16.7:33.3:100 shows that the ratio of hydrogens in the molecule is 1:2:6.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The peak ratios of 1:2:6 show that there is likely to be a total number of 9 hydrogens in the molecule.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The 6H's suggested from the peak area at 1.3 ppm suggests symmetry of two -CH3 groups in the molecule.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Some students attempted to use chemical shifts to justify suggested structural features, but this could not be awarded any marks as the shifts are not reliable and cannot be used effectively in this manner.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: A mark was awarded for each of the following:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The molecule must have three carbon environments.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Symmetry must be present in the molecule in order for the four carbons to show only three peaks.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: As in Question 4d., some students attempted to use chemical shifts to justify suggested structural features, but this could not be awarded any marks as the shifts are not reliable and cannot be used effectively in this manner.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Either isomer of C4H9ClO was accepted but it had to be shown in its skeletal form.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Either 1-chloro-2-methylpropan-1-ol or 2-chloro-2-methylpropan-1-ol.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for recognising that a quinine standard needed to be run under the same conditions and a retention time established.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for recognising that the retention time of the standard needed to match that of the peak in the tonic water in order for the presence of quinine to be possible.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Some students used the argument of 'spiking', which was also accepted.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for recognising that a sample of tonic water needed to be run and then a small quantity of pure quinine was then added to the sample.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for recognising that when the spiked sample was run again, for quinine to be identified as the peak at 1.415 mins, this peak must have increased in size in comparison to the first run.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for recognising that uncontrolled conditions will produce peaks at various retention times and this has the potential to alter the validity of the measurement of peak areas.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for recognising that without valid peaks areas an inaccurate/invalid calibration curve will be generated.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: 'Cannot accurately extrapolate the data' or 'outside of the range of the standards' were accepted.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Hydroxyl or hydroxy.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for identifying Q as the correct structure.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for showing an understanding that there is a change in the functional groups at low pH, i.e. amino groups / amines / nitrogen / bases are subject to protonation / accepting H+ ions.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for recognising that a chiral centre in a molecule arises due to four different substituents being present.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for recognising that these chiral centres generate uniquely shaped isomers.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for recognising that only one of these isomers will have the exact three-dimensional shape / complimentary shape needed to interact with the malaria enzyme's active site.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for recognising that if Q is a more effective inhibitor, it must bind more strongly to the active site.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for the chemical explanation of this by any of the following:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The protonated form can form (ionic) bonds with negatively charged groups within the active site.

Subject: Chemistry
Content:
The protonated form of Q has caused the shape of the molecule to change so it fits better in the 
active site.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: An inhibitor is a molecule that fits into the active site, blocking the substrate from entering.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Literature review.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The mark was awarded for recognising that during a permanganate titration, the end point is denoted when the solution starts to take on the colour of the titrant, i.e. first sign of permanent 'purple' colour.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: 'Pink' could not be accepted as Item 7 of the Databook states that the Mn2+ ion is pink, and this will be steadily forming as the titration reaction takes place.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The mark was awarded for recognising that the increased temperature will cause a faster rate of reaction.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Students responded to this question in two possible ways, both of which were accepted. Responses could be either:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Room temperature would result in a reaction that was too slow to get valid results. OR

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Room temperature was not stated in the methodology, 'boiling' was required. Therefore, this would not be a valid step.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Average titre =  = 15.42 mL (0.01542 L)

Content: The first mark was awarded for the correct calculation of permanganate ion.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for the correct calculation of oxalate ion in aliquot.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for the correct calculation of oxalate ion in spinach sample.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The fourth mark was awarded for the correct calculation of mass of oxalate ion.

Content: The most common issue was students not allowing for dilution or reaction stoichiometry in their calculations.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: % reduction =  =  = 60%

Content: The first mark was awarded for showing an understanding that residual water remaining on the outside of leaves would add soluble oxalate ions into the analysis.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for showing an understanding that this would lead to more permanganate being required or a larger titre of permanganate.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for recognising that 75% was the predicted outcome in the hypothesis.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for making a comparison or a correct statement as to whether the result from Question 6f. was higher than, lower than or the same as the 75% predicted.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Expected responses included:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The first mark was awarded for identifying one relevant green chemistry principle (GCP).

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The second mark was awarded for using evidence to support/explain how the two methods relate to this GCP.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The third mark was awarded for identifying a second relevant GCP.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The fourth mark was awarded for using evidence to support/explain how the two methods relate to this GCP.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The fifth mark was awarded for providing a relevant ethical factor relating to global steel production.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The sixth mark was awarded for a concluding statement that related to the evidence the student provided.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Examples that could have been used for green chemistry principles included:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Prevention of waste

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Data to use

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Comparing the relative amounts of CO2 produced, OR

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Comparing both CO2 and O2 as waste/by-product with respect to their environmental impact.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The blast furnace process has a by-product of little industrial use (CO2), so that becomes waste. MOE has no direct CO2 emissions.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The MOE process has a by-product (O2), but it is less harmful and has some industrial use, so it is not as harmful a 'waste' by-product as CO2.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Design for energy efficiency

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Data to use

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Comparing temperature requirements of the two processes, OR

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Comparing electrical energy requirements of the two processes.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The blast furnace needs more heat energy (2200 compared to 1600). This is more likely done through the burning of fossil fuels.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The MOE process needs more electrical energy than the blast furnace process. It could be argued that the former is not as energy efficient if done by using fossil fuels to produce the electricity. However, it could also be more energy efficient if both the heating stage and the electrolysis stage are done using electricity from renewable energy sources.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Note: Therefore, students could use data to justify either the blast furnace process OR the MOE process for this GCP.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Atom economy

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Data to use

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Atom economy of two reactions, with Fe as the desired product.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Fe from BF process - 62.8%

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Fe from MOE process - 69.9%

Subject: Chemistry
Content: If the worded explanation is reasonable, students would not have to provide detailed mathematical proofs. For example, the blast furnace process has more mass of reactants (C, coke) and an undesired by-product with more mass (CO2 compared to O2), so logically the atom economy of the MOE process should be better.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Examples that could have been used for ethical factors included:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Any discussion connecting the argument that the MOE process would only be green and sustainable if electricity from renewable sources is used, and that access to this will vary significantly across countries/globally.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: For example:

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Renewable energy technology is not set up / accessible in all regions - some steel producers might want to change to the MOE process but cannot do so.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Renewable energy is needed for a lot of things, so an ethical question arises about whether the steel industry should receive priority access over other people/communities/industries.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Steel is produced on a massive scale and provides many jobs; a transition to the MOE process would require large numbers of workers to retrain, and some may lose jobs.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: The MOE process is relatively untested and will take many years to scale up. Meanwhile, society will continue to rely on steel production.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Steel, as a polluting industry, is predominantly produced today in low- to middle-income countries or disadvantaged areas of industrial countries. There is potential for these areas to benefit from a process that uses renewable energy, including health benefits.

Subject: Chemistry
Content: Platinum and iridium are already difficult-to-source (endangered) elements; a global switch to the MOE process would significantly increase demand and extraction of these metals, with hard-to-predict environmental and social consequences.
